publication.title: The Rochester Checkers Player: Multimodel Parallel Programming for Animate Vision
publication.authors: brian d. marsh,christopher brown,thomas j. leblanc,michael l. scott,tim becker,cesar quiroz,prakash das
publication.keyword: Multiple Model;Operating System;Parallel Programming Model;Parallel Programs;Software Requirements;Vision System;
publication.abstract: It is maintained that to exploit fully the parallelism inherent in animate vision systems, an integrated vision architecture must support multiple models of parallelism. To support this claim, the hardware base of a typical animate vision laboratory and the software requirements of applications are described. A brief overview is then given of the Psyche operating system, which was designed to

publication.title: Operating System Support for Animate Vision
publication.authors: brian d. marsh,christopher brown,thomas j. leblanc,michael l. scott,tim becker,prakash das,cesar quiroz
publication.jconf: Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing
publication.keyword: Operating System;Parallel Computer;Parallel Processing;Parallel Programming Model;Programming Model;Robot Motion Planning;Robot Programming;Sensory Processing;Vision System;
publication.abstract: Animate vision systems couple computer vision and robotics to achieve robust and accurate vision, as well as other complex be- havior. These systems combine low-level sensory processing and effector output with high-level cognitive planning-all computa- tionally intensive tasks that can benefit from parallel processing. A typical animate vision application will likely consist of many tasks, each of which may require

publication.title: A Framework for Predictive Data Mining in the Telecommunications Sector
publication.jconf: International Association for Development of the Information Society
publication.abstract: In this paper we construct a framework that enables us to make class predictions about telecommunication companies' financial performances. We have two goals: to validate our methodology and, using it, to gain insights in this relatively new and very sensitive industry: the telecommunications sector. We have obtained high accuracy rates for the classification models, and small differences between training and
